newsitem.title: DENMARK: OECD sees 97 Danish inflation 2.25 pct, 2.75 in 98.
newsitem.headline: OECD sees 97 Danish inflation 2.25 pct, 2.75 in 98.

text.p: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said on Thursday it expected Danish consumer prices to rise by 2.25 percent in 1997 and 2.75 percent in 1998.
The Paris-based group said in its half-yearly report it saw the implicit price deflator at 2.7 percent in 1997 and 3.2 percent the following year.
It expected private consumption to rise 2.9 percent this year and by 2.8 percent in 1998. Unemployment was seen falling from 1996's 8.8 percent to 8.1 percent in 1997 and 7.4 percent in 1998.

Sharply falling unemployment, while helping economic recovery, raised the danger of spiralling wage costs, the report warned. "Rapid job creation could lead to a virtual elimination of the output gap, implying a risk of higher wage inflation."
It saw 1997 GDP growth unchanged from 1996's 2.5 percent and rising to 2.9 percent in 1998. Gross public debt was expected to fall below 70 percent of GDP by 1998.

"Combined with continued tightening of fiscal policy, faster growth should ensure that the general government budget balance moves into surplus, securing a further reduction in interest rate differentials vis-a-vis Germany," it added.
